{{Infobox flag | Name = Flag of Tuscany | Image = Flag_of_Tuscany.svg | Proportion = 2:3 | Adoption = 3 February 1995 | Design = White field, with two red horizontal bands, with a silver Pegasus rampant in the centre }} The '''flag of Tuscany''' is the official flag of the [[Regions of Italy|region]] of [[Tuscany]], [[Italy]]. The flag depicts a silver [[Pegasus]] rampant on a white field between two horizontal red bands. The flag first appeared as a [[gonfalon]] on 20 May 1975 along with accompanying text ''Regione Toscana'' above the Pegasus. It was officially adopted as the flag of Tuscany on 3 February 1995. {{cite web|url=https://www.crwflags.com/fotw/flags/it-tus.html|title=Tuscany Region (Italy)|last=Raeside|first=Rob|date=2016-08-18|website=Flags of the World|publisher=|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=17 February 2020}}{{Cite web|last=Camunlynx|date=2013-10-31|title=Padanian-American League: Pegasus - The flag of Tuscany|url=http://pamle.blogspot.com/2013/11/pegasus-flag-of-tuscany.html|access-date=2020-06-05|website=Padanian-American League}} ==History== The [[Pegasus]] image on the flag derives from a coin made by the Florentine artist [[Benvenuto Cellini]] in 1537. This coin was created by Cellini in order to honour Cardinal [[Pietro Bembo]].{{Cite web|title=Pegasus: history of the symbol of Tuscany|url=https://www.toscanainside.com/hidden-treasures/post/pegasus-history-of-the-symbol-of-tuscany/|access-date=2020-06-05|website=toscanainside.com|language=en}} Bembo was instrumental in the development of the Tuscan language as a literary medium and was honoured with the representation of Pegasus due to its symbolism and ties with creation.{{Cite book|title=The Oxford critical and cultural history of modernist magazines|publisher=|others=Brooker, Peter,, Thacker, Andrew, 1962-|date=26 March 2009|isbn=978-0-19-921115-9|edition=1st|location=Oxford|pages=508|oclc=428818638}} As a result, the Pegasus came to be associated as a symbol of the Tuscan region. The usage of Pegasus by the Tuscan region endured and was adopted by the [[Tuscan Committee of National Liberation]] (CTLN) as a symbol of [[Italian resistance movement|Italian resistance]] in Tuscany to the [[Italian campaign (World War II)|German occupation of Italy]] during the [[World War II|Second World War]].{{Cite web|title=Tuscany Region (Italy)|url=https://www.crwflags.com/fotw/flags/it-tus.html|access-date=2020-06-05|website=www.crwflags.com}} On 11 August 1975, the 26th anniversary of the [[History of Florence|liberation of Florence]], the flag of the [[Tuscan Committee of National Liberation|CTLN]] was symbolically handed over to the [[President of Tuscany]], [[Lelio Lagorio]] by the [[List of mayors of Florence|mayor of Florence]], [[Elio Gabbuggiani]], in a ceremony at the [[Palazzo Vecchio]].{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=|title=The emblem|url=http://www.consiglio.regione.toscana.it/default?nome=marchio|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-06-06|website=Regione Toscana|language=Italian}}This demonstrated the symbolic adoption of the flag of Tuscany by the region. However, the flag was not officially recognised. The flag was officially adopted in 1995 following President [[Oscar Luigi Scalfaro]]'s call for the flag of each Italian region to be represented in the [[Quirinal Palace|Quirinale Palace]]. The usage of the Pegasus was favoured by the [[Regional Council of Tuscany|Tuscan Regional Council]] over a depiction of [[Leonardo da Vinci]]'s [[Vitruvian Man]], as this was considered unsuitable to be reproduced simply.{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=2012-04-02|title=Regione Toscana: Storia: L'adozione del Pegaso|url=http://www.regione.toscana.it/regione/export/RT/sito-RT/Contenuti/Normativa/statuto/Stemma_Marchio/visualizza_asset.html_154171278.html|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402095507/http://www.regione.toscana.it/regione/export/RT/sito-RT/Contenuti/Normativa/statuto/Stemma_Marchio/visualizza_asset.html_154171278.html|archive-date=2012-04-02|access-date=2020-06-06|language=Italian}} The flag is often seen flying outside of Tuscan governmental buildings throughout the region. The seat of the Tuscan Regional Government, [[Palazzo Capponi-Covoni]], is known as the ''Palazzo del Pegaso'' in reference to the flag. The flag also features on the sash used by the [[President of Tuscany]] to distinguish them from other members of the council. == Colours == The usage of the colours red and white to represent the Tuscan region can be dated back to at least the year 969 and the reign of [[Hugh, Margrave of Tuscany]]. He adopted a [[Pale (heraldry)|palleted]] shield of alternating red and white vertical stripes as his coat of arms.{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=|title=(Italiano) Firenze: Ugo di Toscana, Marchese simbolo della citt|url=http://www.thetuscany.net/firenze-ugo-di-toscana-marchese-simbolo-della-citta/?lang=en|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-06-06|website=www.thetuscany.net|language=Italian}} Prominent Tuscan family, the [[Guidi (family)|Guidi]]'s, also adopted a coat of arms coloured in red and white between the 10th and 15th centuries. The Guidi coat of arms depicted a red and silver rampant lion decussated on a red and silver field. The colours also share a similarity to those of the [[flag of Austria]] which widely came to be used as a basis for Tuscan flags whilst Tuscany was ruled by the [[House of Habsburg-Lorraine|Austrian House of Habsburg-Lorraine]] between 1737 and 1848.{{Cite web|title=Tuscany - Historical Flags (Italy)|url=https://www.crwflags.com/fotw/flags/it_tus.html|access-date=2020-06-05|website=www.crwflags.com}}{{Cite web|title=Toscana {{!}} Flag {{!}} Italy {{!}} OzOutback|url=https://ozoutback.com.au/Italy/flags/slides/14Toscana.html|access-date=2020-06-05|website=ozoutback.com.au}}{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=|title=Toscana|url=http://www.rbvex.it/toscana.html|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-06-06|website=www.rbvex.it|language=Italian}} Red and white may also have derived from the traditional usage of the colours in the symbolism of Tuscan towns. For example, the flags and coats of arms of [[Flag of Florence|Florence]], [[Pisa]], [[Republic of Lucca|Lucca]], [[Pistoia]], [[Flag of Elba|Elba]], and [[Grosseto]] all heavily feature the colours red and white.
